body.p: Ulnage (the preferred term in The National Archives) means 'measurement', but in England the word came to be associated with a subsidy levied on high quality woollen cloths. In addition many towns appointed their own ulnagers whose duties were to measure lengths of cloth for sale. The only other country to levy a tax on cloth in medieval Europe was Catalonia, where it was known as bolla.

The king appointed ulnagers, whose duties included buying cloths for his household. There were long-running disputes about the sizes of cloth, and standards were laid down in the Statute of Northampton, 1328. Originally this statute applied to imported cloths but it was extended in 1350 to cover all cloth for sale. The king's ulnagers were so zealous that the number of cloths seized adversely affected trade. In 1353 a compromise was reached and the merchants agreed to pay a levy on each cloth.

There were two parts to the charges, known colloquially as 'the ulnage'. The first was a subsidy of 4d per cloth of assize, worth 13s 4d or more with pro rata payments on larger or smaller cloths, and 6d on scarlets. The revenue went to the Exchequer. In addition there was an ulnage fee of ½d per cloth, or ¼d for half cloths, paid to the ulnager. Worsted cloths were always excluded.

There was a major re-structuring of the administration of the ulnage in 1394. The records from 1394 to 1485 are the most comprehensive, although the revenue was always small. The ulnage lasted until the tax was abolished in 1724. When a merchant paid the tax, a lead seal would be affixed in evidence. Some of these seals have survived and are to be found in museums.

The tax was sometimes administered by ulnagers directly employed by the exchequer and sometimes by 'farmers' (who paid an annual fee and kept all the receipts: see alnagers), but the use of deputies was explicitly not allowed. The directly-employed ulnagers were expected to account in detail for the cloths that they had taxed, whereas the farmers had only to account for their farm fee. Both groups had the power to seize untaxed cloths offered for sale and they had to account for these. The returns describe such cloths and give their value. Seized cloths were valued locally and auctioned.

Nearly all the surviving records are stored in The National Archives (TNA). Most of the appointments of ulnagers are recorded in the Fine Rolls. There are two Ulnage Rolls on which the returns of ulnagers are inscribed. In addition TNA holds a substantial number of particular records. Those of the directly-employed ulnagers of the 1390s, early 1400s and some from the 1460s are reasonably reliable and show who was paying the ulnage. There is a later series from the 1460s and 1470s which is clearly fictitious in part, if not in whole.

The revenue, like most other royal income of the time, was usually allocated in advance and often the ulnagers were authorised to pay it directly to the designated recipients, thereby avoiding the risk and expense of sending it to London. The use of the tax can be ascertained from items in the Patent Rolls and Close Rolls. These include the upkeep of the walls of the city of Winchester, and the maintenance of the king's hunting dogs.
